let's take a look at a traditional
approach of migrating a database to AWS
first you need to create your AWS
account set up your virtual private
cloud in AWS connect to AWS with a VPN
or direct connect shut down and backup
your database transmit the database
backup to s3 configure an ec2 instance
with the database software restore the
backup configure the ec2 instance for
the application and finally switch the
users to AWS if you take a look at steps
four to nine that I've highlighted in
red that process could take a week or
more and that's completely unacceptable
for most customers now there is a better
way whether you want to migrate your
applications to AWS and use easy to or
the managed services you have to work
out how to migrate the databases
securely and ideally with minimal
downtime the AWS database migration
service
or DMS allows you to perform homogeneous
and heterogeneous migrations between the
various databases on the slide here the
migrations can be carried out with
change data capture or CDC this allows
the source database to remain active
during the migration keeping your
application up and running until the
target database has caught up let's take
a look at how DMS works in more detail
on the left hand side you can see the
existing applications databases
on-premise and the users connecting to
that on the right hand side is an AWS
with an empty database ready for

migration we need a replication instance
which is what runs the database
migration service once that is started
you need to provide the connection
information for the source and target
databases next you choose what data you
want to migrate to AWS DMS allows you to
choose specific tables schemas or the
whole database then sit back and let DMS
do the rest
it creates the tables loads of data and
best of all keeps them synchronized for
as long as you need that replication
capability which keeps the source and
target data in sync allows customers to
switch applications over to AWS at their
leisure
this means the DMS eliminates the need
for high-stakes extended outages to

DMS provides a graceful switchover
capability if you have a critical

with the multi AZ option is right for
you it works just like the previous
slide with a single AZ but if something

and continue the respective migration
tasks this is very similar to how RDS
multi AZ works if you are familiar with
that
DMS is managed through a console just
like most AWS services but you can also
use the API to call or script migration
tasks you can set up a replication
instance and tasks in fact you can use
as many replication instances or you can
build as many tasks as you need to run
on those replication instances you can
also choose the power speed and cost of

migrations now for the important rules
you can migrate from on-prem to RDS and

Prem - on Prem migrations so there has
to be an AWS somewhere in the migration
path I mentioned before that we use
change data capture for the migration it
works by capturing the transaction logs
from the source database using log miner
on oracle database or the row level bin
log on my sequel etc this means there is
no need for an argent agent to be
installed on the source database dear
mas just needs a database connection and
we'll use the native interfaces to
extract the data the transaction changes
are sent to the replication instance and
kept there when the bulk load phase
essentially selects our queries is in
progress once the bulk load phase is
complete collected transactions are
applied when that is caught up then DMS
moves into continual apply mode this
means you can keep the source and the
target in sync for as long as you
necessary before failing over to the
target DMS loads the data table by table
there is a default level of parallelism
of 4 tables at a time but it is
customizable to fit your needs
for example on a busy production system
you may only want to do one table at a
time you can also split the data from
one source into multiple targets this is
useful if you have a data warehouse that
you want to extract data from to
populate data Mart's for say finance
marketing and sales teams or you could
take the opposite approach taking
multiple source systems such as
operational systems on-premise and
extracting the data into AWS to populate
a data warehouse you don't need to take
all the data in a given table
you can use a predicate or where clause
to restrict the data that you want to
bring across this could be useful to
only bring the most recent data to the
migrated system rather than bringing all
the data most of which could be archived
anyway when migrating you can choose to
do a homogeneous or heterogeneous
migration for example you could migrate
from Oracle database Enterprise Edition
to exactly the same version and platform
you could also migrate from one version
of Oracle database to another or even
from Standard Edition to Enterprise
Edition you could also migrated from
sequel server to my sequel or from
Oracle database to Aurora

with the AWS database migration service
you pay for the migration instance that

database migration instance includes

space logs and cache inbound data
transfers free

migration service currently supports the
t2 and C for instance classes t2
instances are low costs standard

ability to burst above the baseline
they are suitable for developing and

migration tasks that can benefit from
CPU both capacity C for instances are

process of performance and achieve
significantly higher packet per second
performance they have lower Network
jitter and lower latency too you could
also use the C for instances if you are

not only condemned s migrate your data

if you've ever used other data migration

will understand that they can cost
hundreds of thousands of dollars for
large database migrations so this is a
huge change in the pricing structure DMS
can act as a replication migration Swiss
Army knife but it's not a magic wand use
it for heterogeneous migrations when
minimal downtime is required or there is
no native solution use caution when some

finally if your database is five
terabytes
and you have a slow internet connection

DMS migrates the data we are finding

conversion tools steps in SCT supports
the migration of Oracle database
Microsoft sequel server Maria DB
Postgres and my sequel to any of the

Microsoft sequel server because both

seeing that the schema conversion tool
finds that you are not using any
Enterprise Edition features then it will
recommend that you can use standard
Edition 1 or Standard Edition 2 when
migrating to RDS SCT recent introduced a
new feature data extractors to help
migrate data warehouses this extracts
the data through local migration agents
and optimizes it for loading into Amazon
redshift the files are loaded into an
Amazon s3 bucket or you can use Amazon
snowball as an intermediate step this
then allows you to load them into Amazon
redshift in the best most efficient way

now I'd like to talk about Amazon Arora
that is built upon the RDS platform so
what is Amazon Arora
it's a my sequel compatible and Postgres
compatible relational database platform
with the performance and availability of
the commercial databases delivered as a
migration service AWS announced the my
sequel compatible Edition a tree event
in 2014 and the Postgres compatible
addition at reinvent 2016 if you're
going to build a new database for the
cloud then you don't want to use the
same architecture that has been around
since the 70s
AWS decided to build a new database
platform using a service orientated
architecture the storage layer has been
broken out into a
per database optimize storage service
that receives the database changes in
the form of log entries not filesystem
blocks this is a huge difference and the
main benefit of the Amazon Aurora
platform it is integrated with our AWS
services to help manage Amazon Aurora
such as ec2 Amazon DynamoDB
Amazon simple workflow and Amazon route
53 backups are continuously taken from
the storage service and integrated with
Amazon s3 with eleven nines of
durability you can also create a manual
snapshot and save that an s3 to this
slide demonstrates the large differences
between the storage option operations of
RDS in a multi AZ environment and Amazon
Aurora with the same failover capability
on the left hand side you can see the
RDS my sequel environment and on the
right Amazon Aurora my sequel has a
primary instance and a standby instance
in another availability zone you can
think of a veil ability zone as a data
center the primary database has the
right to Annie BS volume which is
repaired replicated by EBS in the same
AZ at the same time the same right is
sent across to the standby and the same
right to EBS is applied there bin log
files and other metadata is also kept
up-to-date across both instances on
Amazon Aurora there's a primary instance
and a read replica there is no need for
a standby instance that can be accessed
that can't be accessed like an RDS my
sequel this is because replicas become
failover targets in Aurora the storage
is located across six locations in three
AZ's and kept consistent by the storage
service there is a quorum of four needed
for an acknowledge right and three for
read providing a highly resilient
storage tier yet as discussed before the
database just needs to send the logged
or change information to the storage
service and replicate some basic
information to the read replicas this
greatly reduces the amount of i/o that
Aurora needs to do for a given
transaction load increasing the scale
that Aurora can handle when compared to
RDS and traditional databases interval
provides a couple of key technologies
that help with Amazon Aurora
when you encrypt your database the Intel
ASAE SNI feature improves the
performance penalty associated with
encrypting and D encrypting the data
Intel turbo boost technology can help
your queries get a boost of CPU
frequency for spiky workloads that come
into the database to all the other
features mentioned here are available on
the latest AWS instances that are built
with Intel CPUs we only have a short
amount of time and there are so many
features of Aurora so I just want to go
over a few key features as mentioned the
storage is highly available with six
copies across three AZ's and backups are
continuous to s3 with the read replicas
operating on the same storage as the
master instance there is minimal lag
typically less than 20 milliseconds this
solves a big problem for my sequel users
who often have read replicas that lag
into the minutes when there's more than
2,000 IUP's of activity on the primary
database the storage is auto-scaling
it simply adds 10 gigabytes segments as
they are needed the storage service also
identifies hotspots and moves data
around to maximize throughput and
minimize contention recovery is single
threaded with my sequel where as Aurora
does parallel distributed and
asynchronous recovery that greatly
decreases the time that your databases
become available after a restart or
crash this is possible because the
storage engine can apply the log changes
so each storage segment in parallel
related to recovery time is survivable
caches when you restart a relational
database the cache is part of the
database process so the data is lost
however in Aurora the cache is a
separate process that survives a
database process restart this means that
when you restart the database the data
is already available in the cache
preventing the surge and disk activity
that is normally needed to bring the
data into memory before the application
can perform at its peak again normal
database is suffering from such
brownouts as the data is read from the
disks into memory this all contributes
to faster more predictable failover
speaking of faster when Aurora is
compared with my sequel on the same
hardware at scale it is up
five times faster it should be noted
that this is not a single query running
but lots of connections running lots of
queries for Postgres it's more than two
times faster on the same hardware if you
would like to know more AWS has
published the benchmark information and
how to replicate the my sequel
benchmarks on the AWS website when you

then have the same instance and storage

the instance size and then Aurora

allows for adding a new column to my

looks for windows of low activity
suspends the connections performs the

this happens so fast as most users would
